title: 112_s737
content: The Act may be cited as the "Responsible Consumer Financial Protection Regulations Act of 2011" and establishes the Commission. The Consumer Financial Protection Act of 2010 is amended to establish a Commission as the head of the Bureau with the authority to prescribe regulations and issue orders necessary for carrying out the Act. The Commission established under the Consumer Financial Protection Act of 2010 consists of 5 members appointed by the President with Senate approval. Members must be U.S. citizens with expertise in consumer financial protection and serve staggered 5-year terms. The Commission established under the Consumer Financial Protection Act of 2010 consists of 5 members appointed by the President with Senate approval. Members, including the Chair, serve for a term of 5 years and can only be removed for inefficiency, neglect of duty, or malfeasance in office. Vacancies are filled for the remainder of the term, and members can continue to serve until a successor is appointed and confirmed. The Commission under the Consumer Financial Protection Act of 2010 consists of 5 members appointed by the President with Senate approval. Members serve for 5 years and cannot engage in other employment during their term. Not more than 3 members can be from the same political party. The Chair of the Commission is appointed by the President from among the members and serves as the principal executive officer of the Bureau. The Chair of the Bureau, appointed by the President, has executive and administrative functions including personnel supervision, business distribution, and fund use. The Chair is governed by Commission policies and regulations. The Commission's general policies and regulatory decisions guide its actions. Requests for appropriations must be approved by the Commission Chair. Vacancies in the Commission's membership do not limit the remaining members' powers, with three members needed for a quorum. The Commission requires 2 members for a quorum, even with vacancies. The Commission has an official seal and compensates members accordingly. The Chair receives level I Executive Schedule pay, while other members receive level II pay. The Commission requires 2 members for a quorum, even with vacancies. One member can constitute a quorum before the confirmation of at least 2 members. After the confirmation of 2 additional commissioners, the quorum requirements of subsection (f) apply. The Bureau will be included in the regular appropriations process. Section 1017 of the Consumer Financial Protection Act of 2010 is amended to address budget, financial management, and audit. This includes changes to subsections and authorization of appropriations. The Consumer Financial Protection Act of 2010 is amended to authorize appropriations of $143,000,000 for fiscal year 2011 and $329,000,000 for fiscal year 2012 to the Bureau for carrying out the provisions of the Act. The Consumer Financial Protection Act of 2010 authorizes appropriations for the Bureau to carry out the provisions of the Act. SEC. 4. CONFORMING AMENDMENTS. The Consumer Financial Protection Act of 2010 is amended to replace references to the Director with the Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection. The Consumer Financial Protection Act of 2010 is amended to replace references to the Director with the Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection, including changes in titles and positions within the Bureau. The Consumer Financial Protection Act of 2010 is amended to change titles and positions within the Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection, including replacing the Director with the Head of the office and the first member of the Commission. The Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act is also amended accordingly. The Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act is amended to change titles within the Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection, replacing the Director with the Chair of the Commission. Additionally, amendments are made to the Electronic Fund Transfer Act and the Expedited Funds Availability Act. The Consumer Financial Protection Act of 2010 is amended to replace the term "Director of the Bureau" with "Bureau" in various sections of different acts. This change aligns with the amendments made to titles within the Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection, replacing the Director with the Chair of the Commission. The Consumer Financial Protection Act of 2010 replaces the term "Director of the Bureau" with "Bureau" in various sections of different acts, aligning with the amendments made to titles within the Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection. The Sales Full Disclosure Act and the Real Estate Settlement Procedures Act are amended to replace references to the "Director of the Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection" with "Chair" and "Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection" respectively. The S.A.F.E. Mortgage Licensing Act of 2008 and Title 44, United States Code are amended to replace references to the "Director" with "Bureau" in various sections.
